title: The Longer Ending of Mark
description: These 12 verses describe post-resurrection appearances and the Great Commission. Absent from the two oldest Greek manuscripts (Sinaiticus and Vaticanus). Present in most later manuscripts.
fathers: Clement of Alexandria and Origen show no knowledge of it. Eusebius and Jerome note its absence from most Greek manuscripts they knew.
note: The vocabulary and style differ markedly from the rest of Mark. Many scholars believe Mark originally ended at 16:8.

title: The Woman Caught in Adultery (Pericope Adulterae)
description: The famous story of Jesus and the adulterous woman ('Let him who is without sin cast the first stone'). Absent from virtually all early Greek manuscripts. Some manuscripts place it after Luke 21:38 or at the end of John.
fathers: Not mentioned by any Greek father before the 12th century. Ambrose and Augustine in the West knew it. Augustine suggested it was removed because it seemed too lenient on adultery.
note: Almost certainly not original to John's Gospel, but most scholars consider it an authentic early tradition about Jesus.

title: The Johannine Comma (Comma Johanneum)
description: The Trinitarian formula: 'For there are three that bear record in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these three are one.' Found in NO Greek manuscript before the 16th century. A Latin addition that entered the KJV via Erasmus.
manuscripts_against: All early versions (Syriac, Coptic, Armenian, Ethiopic, Arabic, Slavonic)
fathers: No Greek father quotes it, including those who would have had every reason to (e.g., during Trinitarian controversies). First appears in a 4th-century Latin treatise.
note: Erasmus included it in his 3rd edition (1522) only because a single late manuscript was produced on demand. Universally rejected by modern textual scholars.

title: The Ethiopian Eunuch's Confession
description: 'And Philip said, If thou believest with all thine heart, thou mayest. And he answered and said, I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.' Absent from the oldest manuscripts.
fathers: Irenaeus quotes a similar text. Cyprian also knows it.
note: Likely a marginal gloss reflecting early baptismal practice that was later incorporated into the text.

title: The Doxology of the Lord's Prayer
description: 'For thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, for ever. Amen.' This familiar ending to the Lord's Prayer is absent from the earliest manuscripts.
fathers: Absent from citations by Tertullian, Origen, Cyprian. Present in the Didache (late 1st/early 2nd century).
note: Likely a liturgical addition. Luke's version of the Lord's Prayer (Luke 11:2-4) also lacks it.

title: The Bloody Sweat in Gethsemane
description: An angel strengthens Jesus, and his sweat becomes like drops of blood. Present in some early manuscripts but absent from others.
fathers: Justin Martyr, Irenaeus, and Hippolytus appear to know it. Some scholars suggest it was removed because it portrayed Jesus as too human.
note: The manuscript evidence is genuinely divided. UBS gives it a {C} rating (considerable difficulty).

title: 'Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do'
description: Jesus' prayer of forgiveness from the cross. Absent from several important early manuscripts.
fathers: Widely quoted by early fathers. Some suggest it was removed by scribes who felt God should not forgive those who crucified Christ.
note: More likely original than not. UBS includes it in brackets.

title: The Angel Stirring the Water
description: The explanation that an angel periodically stirred the pool of Bethesda, and the first person in was healed. Absent from the earliest and best manuscripts.
fathers: Tertullian appears to know the tradition. Not widely cited by early fathers.
note: Almost certainly a later addition explaining why people gathered at the pool.

title: The Grace Benediction
description: 'The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.' A near-duplicate of 16:20b.
fathers: Not cited by early fathers as a separate verse.
note: A scribal duplication of the benediction in 16:20. Omitted by all modern critical texts.

title: Prayer and Fasting
description: 'Howbeit this kind goeth not out but by prayer and fasting.' Parallels Mark 9:29.
fathers: Widely known in later tradition.
note: Likely imported from Mark 9:29 by scribes who wanted Matthew to include this teaching.

title: 'For the Son of man is come to save that which was lost'
description: This verse parallels Luke 19:10. Absent from the oldest manuscripts of Matthew.
fathers: Origen does not include it in his commentary on Matthew.
note: Assimilated from Luke 19:10 by later scribes.

title: Woe Against Devouring Widows' Houses
description: 'Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye devour widows' houses...' Parallels Mark 12:40 / Luke 20:47.
fathers: Not consistently placed — some manuscripts put it before v.13, others after.
note: Assimilated from Mark 12:40 and/or Luke 20:47.

title: Repeated Refrain on Hell
description: 'Where their worm dieth not, and the fire is not quenched.' Verses 44 and 46 repeat the words of verse 48.
fathers: The refrain (from Isaiah 66:24) is genuine at v.48; the repetitions in v.44 and v.46 are scribal additions for emphasis.
note: Scribes added the refrain after each of the three warnings for rhetorical symmetry.

title: Unforgiveness Warning
description: 'But if ye do not forgive, neither will your Father which is in heaven forgive your trespasses.'
fathers: Imported from Matthew 6:15.
note: A scribal harmonization with Matthew's Sermon on the Mount.

title: Isaiah 53:12 Fulfillment
description: 'And the scripture was fulfilled, which saith, And he was numbered with the transgressors.'
fathers: Imported from Luke 22:37.
note: A scribal addition from Luke's account.

title: 'Only-begotten God' vs 'Only-begotten Son'
description: The earliest manuscripts read 'the only-begotten God' (μονογενὴς θεός) rather than the familiar 'the only-begotten Son' (μονογενὴς υἱός).
fathers: Clement of Alexandria, Origen, and other early fathers quote 'God.' Later fathers tend to quote 'Son.'
note: 'Only-begotten God' is the harder reading and has the best manuscript support. 'Son' likely arose from scribal familiarity with John 3:16.

title: 'His father' vs 'Joseph'
description: The earliest manuscripts read 'his father and mother marveled' rather than 'Joseph and his mother.' Scribes likely changed it to protect the doctrine of the virgin birth.
fathers: Most modern critical texts read 'his father.'
note: An example of a 'theological correction' by scribes.

title: 'His parents' vs 'Joseph and his mother'
description: Similar to 2:33 — the earliest manuscripts read 'his parents' but some scribes changed it to 'Joseph and his mother' to avoid implying Joseph was Jesus' biological father.
fathers: Another example of scribal theological sensitivity.
note: Luke himself uses 'his parents' and 'your father' (2:48) without any concern about the virgin birth.

title: 'Asaph' vs 'Asa' / 'Amos' vs 'Amon'
description: The earliest manuscripts of Matthew's genealogy read 'Asaph' (the psalm-writer) and 'Amos' (the prophet) instead of the kings Asa and Amon. Later scribes 'corrected' them.
fathers: The original readings may be deliberate by Matthew, linking the genealogy to worship (Asaph) and prophecy (Amos).
note: A fascinating case where the 'wrong' reading is likely the original.

title: 666 vs 616
description: Most manuscripts read 'six hundred sixty-six' (χξϛ) but P115 (the earliest witness, c. 275 AD) and a few other manuscripts read 'six hundred sixteen' (χιϛ).
fathers: Irenaeus (Against Heresies V.30.1) knew of the 616 variant but argued for 666.
note: 616 is the value of 'Nero Caesar' in Latin; 666 is the value in Hebrew. Both may point to Nero.

title: 'By the grace of God' vs 'Apart from God'
description: Most manuscripts read 'by the grace of God he might taste death for everyone.' A few early witnesses read 'apart from God' (χωρὶς θεοῦ instead of χάριτι θεοῦ).
fathers: Origen knew both readings. 'Apart from God' may mean Christ died for everything except God himself.
note: 'By the grace of God' has overwhelmingly better manuscript support.

title: 'Who is in heaven' — present or omitted
description: KJV includes 'which is in heaven' (ὁ ὢν ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ), describing the Son of Man as simultaneously in heaven while speaking on earth. Absent from earliest manuscripts.
fathers: Origen and some early fathers cite it with the phrase.
note: The phrase may be a scribal theological addition emphasizing Christ's divine omnipresence.

title: 'God was manifest in the flesh' vs 'He who was manifest'
description: KJV reads 'God was manifest in the flesh' (θεός). Critical texts read 'He who was manifested' (ὅς). The difference is a single stroke: ΟΣ vs ΘΣ.
fathers: The earliest citations use 'who' (ὅς). 'God' appears from the 4th century onward.
note: The abbreviation ΘΣ (God) differs from ΟΣ (who) by only a tiny crossbar and an accent. A classic example of accidental or intentional scribal alteration.

title: 'Without a cause' — present or omitted
description: KJV: 'whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause' (εἰκῇ). Critical texts omit 'without a cause,' making the teaching more absolute.
fathers: Origen notes that 'without a cause' is absent from some manuscripts.
note: 'Without a cause' may have been added by scribes who found the absolute prohibition too strict.

title: For God so loved the world
description: Universally attested across all manuscript traditions with no significant variants.
fathers: Quoted by virtually every church father.
note: One of the best-attested verses in the entire New Testament.

title: The Gospel Creed
description: 'Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures, was buried, rose again the third day.' The earliest Christian creed, dating to within 3-5 years of the crucifixion.
fathers: Paul says he 'received' this tradition — it predates his letters. Universally quoted.
note: Scholars across the spectrum agree this is the earliest datable Christian tradition.

title: 'God works all things' vs 'all things work together'
description: A subtle but theologically significant variant: does God actively work all things for good, or do all things passively work together?
fathers: Both readings are ancient.
note: Modern critical texts tend to read 'God works all things together for good' with an explicit divine subject.
